George Allen. England. died (recently)Ruskin's Publishers.Liberty: 1907, Vol XVI No. 4. 400 OctoberTucker in mentioning his death speaks of having started in search of an edition of Ruskin ("33 years ago") 1874 when he went to England. Tucker went to Kent to find an edition of Ruskin, boycotted at the time. He found George Allen. Mr. Ruskin was in Italy. Mr. Allen gave him a set of Ruskin and a portrait & autographed letter and other things greatly[reverse]prized by the 20 year old Tucker.(It is a reference that throws light on his 1874 stay in Europe.)

Altgeld, John Peter.Material saved by George A. Schilling and given by Harry Barnard in 1940-1941Sent to Agnes Inglis - Labadie CollectionWhen the Illinois State Historical Library at Springfield, Illinois decided to establish a Memorial Center to John Peter Altgeld to assemble all material possible on Altgeld, both Harry Barnard and Agnes Inglis agreed the Schilling Material belonged in Illinois with the Altgeld material. I, therefore, went over it, keeping duplicates, having originals photostated, to keep. Keeping only a over[reverse]few things for the Labadie Collection saved by George A. Schilling that had some personal or historic relation to either Schilling or Altgeld.The rest all went back to Illinois.Sent to the Librarian, Mr. Paul Anglesigned: Agnes InglisMay 4, 1941

John Peter Altgeld (1847-1902)Governor of Illinois.In 1893 he freed from prison three men, life-time prisoners, accused, in 1886, of having had a part in the Haymarket affair. He both freed them and affirmed their innocence. A book published in 1938 brought Altgeld again into prominence. The book is entitled "Eagle Forgotten: The Life of John Peter Altgeld," by Harry Barnard. Bobbs-Merrill Company publishers, Indianapolis and New York.

Alwato was a "scientific" language invented by Stephen Pearl Andrews. Ref: The primary synopsis of universology and Alwato : the new scientific universal language / by Stephen Pearl Andrews. Pub. New York : D. Thomas, 1871.

Liberty, July 11, 1891[clipping]The Science of Society by Stephen Pearl Andrews.This work, long out of print, is now republished to meet a demand which for a few years past has been rapidly growing. First published about forty years ago, and yet in its teachings still far in advance of the times, it comes to the present generation practically as a new book. Josiah Warren, whose social philosophy it was written to expound, was in the habit of referring to it as the most lucid and complete presentation of this ideas that ever had been written or ever could be written. It will undoubtedly take rank in the future among the famous books of the nineteenth century.It consists of two parts, as follows:Part I. The True Constitution of Government in the Sovereignty of the Individual as the Final Development of Protestantism, Democracy, and Socialism.Part II. Cost the Limit of Price: A Scientific Measure of Honesty in Trade, as one of the Fundamental Principles in the Solution of the Social Problem.Price, in Cloth, One Dollar.Address the Publisher: Sarah E. Holmes, Box 3366, Boston, Mass.

Stephen Pearl Andrews1876. "The Index."Following the discussion over Proudhon in the Index between Stephen Pearl Andrews and Benj. R. Tucker - and Wm. B. Greene, on the side of Tucker and Proudhon, the Index printed a series of communications in issues of Oct. 26, Nov. 23, and Dec. 14th, 1876 by Stephen Pearl Andrews under the heading "The Science of Universology," 1, 2 & 3. He does this at the request of Mr. Greene. These clippings he saved: they are in his "Envelope" Libertarian People file case.The discussion ended August 10th, 1876.

Stephen Pearl Andrews and Josiah Warren and "The Science of Society"Stephen Pearl Andrews tells about 1851.Reference: Woodhull & Claflin's Weekly, 1871, August 5th"I became acquainted with Mr. Warren's peculiar and invaluable scheme of socialist ideas in 1851: and I write and published that same year, I believe, a word entitled 'Science of Society', now out of type, which was little more than my exposition of his ideas." *** S.P.A. Andrews goes on to say he agreed with these ideas, although not always agreeing with Warren on other subjects.

"L'en dehors." French Lang. Serial MonthlyE. Armand22, cite Saint JosephOrleans, France.Organe d'education de realization de camaradie individualiste anarchisteIssues 1922-1939, Nos. 1-335, completeNote: E. Armand edited "l'Era Nouvelle" 1901-1906; "Les Refractaires" 1912-1914; "Par dela la melee", 1916-1918; so his publications ran from 1901-1939. The last issue of "L'en dehors" is no. 335, October 1939, consisting of one page of one sheet, giving an account of "L'en dehors" and its predecessors, some of which are in the Collection. He is also the author and publisher of many books and pamphlets which he has donated[reverse]to the Collection. His first donations were to Joe Labadie. Some of Joe Labadie's poems he translated and published in his publications; he was, himself, a poet. After Joe Labadie's death he donated his works directly to the Collection - up to October, 1939Complete in Labadie CollectionNo. 1 (1922) - No. 335: 18 annee, Oct. 1939

E. Armand et son œuvre"Tout le monde n'aime pas E. Armand," écrivait Gérard de Lacaze-Duthiers dan "Le Semeus" du 20 janvier 1926. Ce n'est pas une raison pour le calomnier ou le diffamer, même si le calomniateur ou le diffamateur est la proie du gâtisme sénile. La meilleure réponse, heureusement, aux injures et aux insulttes est dans "l'œuvre" de notre camarade: la voici, cidessous, détaillée de façon aussi complète que possible.

In my research as to what the heading of the card should be, I came across Carlene Bagnall's obituary, dated July 15, 2010. She had earned a PhD in English and Women's Studies at Michigan and later became a professor of Women's Studies at Michigan. She was extensively involved with peace and non-violent activities throughout her life.

Survey Graphic, May 1, 1928The Daughters of the American Revolution have been saved from becoming the laughing-stock of the country. The New York Times, for instance, made high fun of their blacklist, which came out on the heels of April Fool's Day and solemnly set down "our too, too solid friend William Allen White" of Kansas as a "socialist." Mr. White himself tossed on the ball of ridicule with such delicious trimmings as "tea gladiators" and "nice old girls." But a few days later came a vigorous pamphlet, Our Threatened Heritage, a Letter to the D.A.R., in which Helen Tufts Bailie, of Cambridge, Massachusetts, and fourteen other members protest that "our society has been duped." They point out that the person discriminated against as speakers before chapter meetings "are religious, educational, political and social science leaders," and they deplore the fact that "our splendid organization has become a tail to the kite of ignorant, misguided or designing persons." They trace the list back to the discredited Lusk report, "the activities of the Department of Justice under Palmer, Daugherty and Burns" and Fred R. Marvin of the "Key Men of America." Mrs. Bailie stops the laughter not only by her serious concern for the "fellow-citizens whom we have grossly and unfairly abused," but by her demonstration that the fighting blood among the Daughters is not confined to lobbying for a bigger navy; that there is an insurgent wing which believes in liberties the foremothers thought worth sacrifice.
There is no card. Just a clipping from a publication. The phrase "Mrs. Bailie" in the second half of the article has been underlined.

N.W.With a preface by Carlo Cafiero and Elisee Reclus.(First French Edition - "Preface-Geneve, 1882")"A New Edition, Revised from the Original Manuscript""Introductory Remarks" by M. Nettlau, Nov 24, 1908 in which he says "Benj. R. Tucker's translation forms the basis of the present amended edition."63 pages - paper-covered bookAnarchist Section Box Booklets "Michael Bakunin"over[reverse]In sending this "Freedom - 1910" edition, Thomas H. Keell writes (Jan. 9 1936) see Correspondence- as follows. "You ask for data about 'God and the State.' The first English translation was by Benj. R. Tucker (Boston 1883). This translation was reprinted by the 'Commonwealth' (London, 1894). 'The Free Society' edition must also have been a reprint of Tucker's translation. In 1910 Freedom Press published 'A New Edition Revised from the Original Manuscript' by M. Nettlau, who wrote an 'Introductory Remark' as a preface, giving the history of the work, and concluding by saying: 'Benj. R. Tucker's translation forms the basis of the present amended edition.' When Emma Goldman published 'God and the State' (1916 or 1917--there is no date on it), she used this amended edition, but did not publish Nettlau's 'Introductory Remark,' much to his disgust, nor was the translator or revisor
Note: The text continues on the next card.

mentioned. To crown everything, on the title-page was printed 'First American edition'!! It certainly was the first American edition of the amended edition, but the ordinary reader would have no idea that an American edition of 'G & S' was published over thirty years before."See "FREEDOM", England: Vol. XXIV, 1910, No. 249 (January)"God and the State": A new edition revised from the original Manuscript
Note: The text continues Keell's quote from the previous card.

Berkman, AlexanderBerkman was put out of France on May Day, 1930. The reason was that he was editor of the "Bulletin" for the Political Prisoners in Russia. He was obliged to discontinue the work in order to stay on earth. Once is obliged to stay somewhere on earth while here. So Rudolph Rocker took the editorship of it. See "The Bulletin," 1930, Nov., Dec.

In reality, it doesn't amount to anything excepting to put the society in a false position before the public."

Bowen, Paul T. - (who, by the way, is a Michigan man) of Excelsior Assembly, 2672 one of the brightest of the many able men for which that assembly is noted....etc."signed "LEUMAS"Detroit Labor Leaf, Vol. II, No. 3, November 25, 1885Note: In 1889 he was one of the four delegates to the Labor Congress at Paris, France, and also to the Typo Congress at that time and place.

Bowen, Paul TaborLetter to George A. Schilling dated July 24, 1893 - Letterhead, Washington D.C.Office of the Fourth Auditor, Treasury Dept.He wanted from George A. Schilling if possible 300 of 2000 printed pamphlets. He hopes Gov. Altgeld prepares an exhaustive review of the anarchist case & that it will be published. He belongs to the D.A. Knights of Labor in Washington D.C. He speaks of those who stand for the condemned men & of the revival of interest in the case and how it is uniting all groups. It is a fine letter. See Haymarket Case Box.[reverse]A photostat copy of the original letter is in the Labadie Collection, Haymarket Box of Material: The original letter is with the Altgeld Material in the Illinois State Historical Society Library - Springfield, Illinois.
